Hi Ron;

My Onin is just under 2.omm in thickness, and 77.0mm in diameter.

John
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Ron Polansky 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Saturday, June 28, 2003 8:28 PM
  Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Early sukashi tsuba attribution


  Jim/John/Gents:

  Thanks very much for the help!
  Kyo-Shoami it is on the sukashi guard.

  On the other, Onin makes absolute sense..and the pics of John's 
  tsuba look right on (plate and ring)
  Btw, the rim is 3.5 mm and is uniform on the Onin tsuba..

  Thanks again,
  Ron P.

  --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "John Berta" <johnberta@t...> 
  wrote:
  > Hi Ron;
  > 
  > I think Jim is right on the money.
  > 
  > I have a tsuba very similar to your Onin tsuba but it has a 
  constellation in negative sukashi with the brass outline just as Jim 
  described.  her is the link,
  > 
  > http://www3.telus.net/sword/sword/index.htm/My%20Webs6/tsb1gal.htm
  > 
  > John
  >   ----- Original Message ----- 
  >   From: Jim Gilbert 
  >   To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  >   Sent: Saturday, June 28, 2003 9:34 AM
  >   Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Early sukashi tsuba attribution
  > 
  > 
  >   Ron,
  >   The broad seppa dai and the shape of the hitsuana are seen in 
  Owari tsuba.  The style of the sukashi is more like Kyo work, 
  though.  It's difficult to judge iron from photographs, but it 
  doesn't look typically Owari.  I've seen guards that looked quite 
  like Owari be judged as Shoami because of uncertainty over the lack 
  of some classic characteristic or other.  Some of these sukashi 
  pieces can be very difficult to pigeonhole with confidence because 
  they share characteristics of Kyo and Owari.  My guess is that your 
  guard would be attributed to Shoami.  Probably early Edo period or a 
  bit older.
  > 
  >   The other guard is interesting.  Some of that type have plates 
  like Kamakura bori and have a simple carving around the rim.  Others 
  have plates more like Onin guards.  Both types can have a simple 
  ring or two of brass inlay.  I don't think I've seen an example that 
  has the rim hammered like yours, but aesthetically it seems like the 
  same idea as the carved decoration seen on others.
  > 
  >   The style of the plate, the shape of the kozuka ana and the 
  simple inlay decoration would all point to an Onin attribution.    
  How thick is it?  Probably mid Muromachi at least.
  > 
  >   Jim
  > 
  > 
  >     Gentlemen:
  > 
  >     I really have problems with attribution on these early tsuba:
  >     http://www.nihontophile.com/Suk1.jpg
  >     http://www.nihontophile.com/Suk2.jpg
  >     http://www.nihontophile.com/Suk3.jpg
  >     Tsuba is 7.2 tall x 6.9 cm wide; 4 mm thick at the mimi.
  >     I first thought Ko-Shoami because of the fine sukashi work.
  >     But it looks Owari (and has bones in the rim). However it is 
  on the 
  >     small side..which would place it late but it looks early and 
  has 
  >     obviously been mounted many times.
  >     What about Kyo-Shoami?
  >     (perhaps some day I will get it down.....:)
  > 
  >     Also this tsuba has given me a fit as to attribution/age:
  >     http://www.nihontophile.com/html/gallery.html
  > 
  >     Any help would be much appreciated.
  > 
  >     Kind regards,
  >     Ron P.
  >
